This game is an odd one. Every single criticism that you've heard about this game just might be valid, but that still doesn't hinder my recommendation of this game.

Yes, the recoil on the guns is absurd. This isn't a problem, because bullets are much more damaging when they actually hit what you want them to.

Yes, the characters are all but unlikable. However, this seems to be intentional, as IO interactive stated in an interview before release that you shouldn't be trying to do so. Think about movies like The Departed. There's nobody to root for, not even the titular protagonists. Fortunately, the further you progress, the more that Kane and Lynch ♥♥♥♥ up. reviewText:
Live a 18 rated action movie.

The Good:
* Captures the look, feel & language of a Tarantino movie
* Great characters that really fit their parts
* Diverse locations make the most of it's cinematic leanings
* Action is delivered in set-pieces that have a natural flow
* Guns are horribly inaccurate which is oddly a good thing
* Buddy AI was good and the revival system (as copied in FarCry2) is neat
* Nice simple objectives and weapons system
* Great weapon sounds

The Bad:
* On Steam you have to manually installed Games for windows (xliveredist/) before it will start
* Engine shows it's age with tearing and jaggy shadows
* Many set-pieces are too easy, at odds with the hardcore feel
* Dumb enemy AI breaks the immersion as cops charge you
* Environment interferes with your aim but cops shoot through walls
* Cover mechanic is awkward and often fails to trigger
* Violence is hardcore (to men and women)
* Ending is anticlimatic after a perfect set-up.
* 5-6 hours tops and you are done.

Background: Had heard good and bad about it but was interested by the characters and plot. Also fan of the Hitman series by IO software too. Not interested in multiplayer.

Impressions: A pleasant surprise indeed. The console port feel doesn't spoil the thrill ride of a hardcore FPS with a strong cinematic leanings. The story is serviceable but it's the characters, their looks and development that surprised me in good ways. There are a lot of unpolished elements with the cover, shooting and AI but the general gameplay is good enough to keep you playing. While the ending was controversial I was OK with it and interested enough to play K&L2.

Recommended for: Adults only who don't mind very gritty violence and language.

Conclusion: 7/10. Fun, violent, slightly buggy, memorable & short.

reviewText: As the Eidos publicity machine readied itself to push its new shooter, the two lead characters that emerged as the stars of IO Entertainment's gruesome crime caper presented themselves as some of the most irreverent in gaming's history. The pair that make up Kane & Lynch may sound like a duo from a buddy movie where two rule-bending cops save the day, but they are in fact deeply disturbed convicts, broken out of prison by balaclava-clad henchmen, so they may repay a debt to a mysterious crime organisation.You assume the role of Kane; a monstrous killer with a good man trapped inside of him, who has had his wife and child kidnapped while he is serving time, meaning he must jump to the fiddle of a group called The Seven, who will destroy the remnants of his family life without blinking. Kane is consumed by rage and sadness, but has a touch of Max Payne about him. He has almost nothing to lose, and will stop at nothing to get to his wife and daughter, and it's hard not to warm to him even though he is a dangerous killer.Lynch is your side kick; a violent maniac who's psychological profile would likely read like there had been a serious administrative error in a psychiatrist's filing cabinet.He is prone to attacks of intense hallucinations, that usually stir him into a trigger-happy frenzy where innocent bystanders are fair game, and is sent to watch over you as you struggle to return a mysterious bounty to The Seven. With such intriguing and powerful characters it's easy to get swept in by Kane & Lynch: Dead Men, but after several hours of play, it is going to be the gameplay that really matters.In that regard, Dead Men is of mixed success.There are times when the best technique is to charge head on with scant regard for accurate aiming, fighting with fists and shooting from the hip. Then, a moment later you're expected to work your way forward methodically, picking enemies off from quite a distance. While variety is desperately needed in most shooters, here it is too sporadic, and often hopping between the two is rather confusing.There's also the fact that the targeting reticule blends into the background with infuriating ease, and the tendency of weapons to spread their ammunitions means while they are great for close exchanges of fire, missions with an emphasis on ranged shooting can be incredibly annoying. In every game mode snapping on to cover is unreliable, and the basic controls for climbing never seem to work particularly well. For every staggering set piece there is a niggling problem, and it means that while we all wanted Kane & Lynch to be near perfect, it is instead ever so slightly flawed. The visuals are as mixed as the rest of the game. Sometimes stylish and detailed, Kane & Lynch can also come across as rather rough and untidy.If you enjoy games with decent plots, developed characters and decent dialogue, this violent, offensive and witty action game is probably worth your attention, and if you're a shooting game purist, try not to expect too much.

reviewText:
I'm not going to pretend that this game is perfect.  Read enough of the other reviews and you will clearly see that people are mixed on this game.  I'm also not going to touch on the review scandal.  That was an ugly bit of business, but it doesn't impact the game on its own merits.  It showcases how scummy the company is that made the game.

I like the characters overall.  The gang of mercs that you build up has their own personalities and each one adds to the story a little bit, but the center is on Kane and Lynch.  The banter between these 2 during the course of a mission can be a lot of fun to listen to and it helps drive the story a little bit further.  Games like this usually don't have much of a story to them, but this one has little pockets waiting to be seen, if you give it a chance.

It's not without issues, though.  The cover system, while functional at times, does not always work and sometimes you will snap into cover at odd angles or stupid moments and it won't work when you always need it to.  Gunfire definitely drives your aim skyward, but that is a relaistic idea (even if it seems too aggressive in this game).  Enemies do take a fair number of hits to put them down, but if you're in that much of a bad situation, you can always switch to your pistol and go for headshots.

The music and sound effects are great and, again, the banter between the characters will keep things moving.  Sure, profanity abounds in this, but given the source material, what did you expect?

Overall, a mix of locations (and the club shows how many people you can put on a screen at one time... nice chaotic atmosphere that makes it harder to get by without killing any innocents) keeps things interesting and varied.  There aren't too many guns, but there are enough to get the job done and give you a little freedom to determine what works best for you.

Is it perfect?  Hell no.  Will you get frustrated with the things that don't work well?  Quite possibly.  But is it worth giving it a try to enjoy what does work?  Yes, I think it is.

If you’re a fan of Michael Manns films, then rest assured, you’re going to enjoy Kane & Lynch: Dead Men. From the L.A Bank heist shootout to the Nightclub showdown, you’ll have a vague idea what rests ahead.

Visually, the Hitman: Blood Money game engine has dated well. And holds up to many games this current generation with well-rounded reflections, shadows and environmental destruction which add a sense of realism and immersion into the game world. Cut scenes suffer from audio cutting out resulting in the end of the conversations missing, while the addition of sub-titles makes this issue smaller, the end result is a still mildly frustrating. As for the voice acting, Lynch leaves something to be desired but the voice acting for Kane adds much more to the character of this flawed man.

Mechanically, while it works, the cover system is “clunky” at best; resulting in poor cover mechanic and a sub-par targeting system with precision targeting is almost non-existent in the game.

Gameplay-wise, Kane & Lynch is a kinetic and non-stop experience, shooting and seeking cover is exiting whenever you can control it. Although it can get repetitive at times, there’s no stop sign to show at you by the constant number of henchmen coming at you. The command system that plays out in a strategic way where you can command your team mates/NPC’s to target selected enemies or take cover; however it was an under-exploited system because you will find yourself doing all the shooting due to the poor AI.

Kane & Lynch is a thrilling but very violent and masochistic action game. You have the opportunity to end the lives of innocent bystanders to even hearing the voice of a cop beg for their life because they have children; all while the wife and daughter of Kane are held captive. The story follows at a psychological drama emotional vibe, and certain strong elements that would put the player in enough stress if it isn't by the story's way of destroying up the characters’ lives, and although it doesn't grab enough interest on its character development it does at least satisfy you with those individual personalities of each that makes a credible duo that are not precisely role models nor does it glamourize the lifestyle of the protagonist which many games or movies lean towards to justify their actions.

Exciting, ultra-violent, masochistic guilt, pulse pounding vengeance, searing vulgarity and Japanese gangsters in leather motorcycle outfits, this game has every top-notch action film element one could ask for.

Overall, a relatively fun local co-op game to play at home with a friend. Kane and Lynch: Dead Men is a 3rd person shooter, with a reasonable plot with some interesting locations and scenarios such as robbing a bank, breaking people out of prison. However gameplay had a turn for the worse when they went to Havana onwards, where you suddenly turned into some army commando fighting against armies of soldiers. I only played on local co-op on game pads, so i'll be reviewing based on the gameplay i experienced. I'd only recommend buying it if extremely cheap on offer, especially if you are looking for something to play with a friend at home. Options are relatively limited for couch co-op play at the moment, so this option gives this game a good plus point.

Pros:
+ Reasonable story line
+ Kane and Lynch make great main characters for the game
+ Some nice scenarios
+ Multiple endings
+ Local Couch Co-op
+ Gamepad support

Cons:
- Uses Games for Windows Live, which means you have to create an X-Box Live profile and install another bit of software. Takes a little bit of time to set up.
- Quite a short campaign.
- Awful AI in enemies and your squad of men that follow you. Came across one situation where we couldn't get through to the next access point in Havana because one of our men had decided to get on a fixed gun despite all enemies being dead. There was a generic army guy following us in his place. Trying to get him to come with us was annoying because he kept jumping back on the gun as soon as we got him out of it.
- Enemies have ridiculosly good aim from far away and don't suffer from any recoil.
- Poor gamepad controls: looking is way too unsensitive even when on maximum settings, Lynch's gamepad settings always changed to the default again every time you started the game.
- Some game controls you almost never end up using, such as passing eachother weapons, or giving orders to your squad, but that could be down to the very short campign however.
- Awful automatic wall cover system, which rarely ever works, and when it does it happens when you don't want it to.
- Bullets and grenades clipping off air when you try to shoot or throw them near a corner of a wall. Throwing grenades while in cover can be disastrous.
- Grenades are pretty crap in general.
- Lynch in the side of the car in one of later missions has almost zero range to shoot anything. In the same mission, there are enemies that can be driving and shooting you from behind, but no one can turn around to shoot at them.
- All achievements are for Games for Windows Live, and non existant on Steam.

My Score: 6/10

This is Kane and Lynch: Dead Men.

Hilarious and frustrating at the same time.

The plot was very engaging to me and i really felt for Kane as he struggled throughout the game but the ending left me thinking..
there was a decision but which decision was the canon ending?

It didn't take me too long to finish the campaign, i was hoping it would be a tad bit longer. I was hooked on the story, i wanted more of Kane and Lynch.

Oh and if you can get past your hate of GFWL, then you can enjoy the singleplayer (maybe even the Co-op if you are lucky.) campaign cause multiplayer seems pretty damn dead.

7/10 would play again after GFWL gets patched out

reviewText:
I enjoyed Kane and Lynch 2: Dog Days a lot, and bought the first game a few years after that.
I must say, I enjoyed the first game too, but I think that it's too short, and quite annoying at some places. The AI companions can't take cover properly, and they can't revive each other if they are downed - you must revive them yourself.

There's no reload button, the character reloads automatically. Which means, that sometimes he starts reloading when you are just about to jump out of cover to shoot. Or, he won't start reloading and you jump on enemies from behind with almost empty mag.

Cover system is similar to Mass Effect 1 - when you approach an obstacle, the character will take cover automatically.
I've only had slight problems with this, and that the camera angles from cover are very badly synced with your aim. Most of the time when I peak out of cover, the shots are hitting the wall which I was taking cover at.

Atmosphere is good, the game has the exact feel - dark, criminal, unfortunate. I don't like Kane, he's both uninteresting and makes wrong decisions. Also constantly refuses Lynch's suggestions, then he pays for it.

Had no technical problems, apart from wrong installation - I had to manually go to game's folder and install GFWL support. It also constantly ran at 60+ FPS on max details. The graphics are avarage, enviroments sometimes feel empty. Characters look good though.
Fortunately, you don't need to login to GFWL to play the game, so the presence of GFWL has no effect. Don't be afraid of it.

Overall, it's a good game, but I don't recommend it because of auto-reloading and auto-cover systems that can cause trouble. Also it's very short (4 hours), companions are dumb at certain situations, and Kane is annoying character.

The Kane and Lynch 2 is a great though, it pretty much gets rid of EVERY negative points I mentioned in this review for Kane and Lynch 1. I recommend checking the second game.

reviewText:
All in all, a barely average game. It has its moments, but the bland gameplay is what holds it back. K&L's story was the only thing keeping me hooked and is where the game truly shines. The gritty criminal underworld atmosphere, the diverse characters with layers and flaws, and the pursuit of vengeance make for a great tale. It all feels like a mindless action movie at times, which is fun. Kane and Lynch's conflicting personalities and little quips make for a good laugh as well. The plot is actually pretty dark, which I enjoyed immensely. Had playing the actual game not been so tedious, I'd agree that this is an underrated title.

But this is where the game fell flat. The cover-based third person shooting isn't special in any way, and gets old fast. Sure, it's a short game (3.5 hours for me on normal with more than a couple of deaths), but the shooting doesn't feel invigorating enough to excite me. It all felt like a chore. There are some challenging stealth portions, which made for nice breaks, but they were few and far between.

Granted, I did play this title solo. Maybe co-op is more fun, but I can't say as I didn't feel interested enough to try it. It's not an expensive game, and is dirt cheap especially on sale. If you're on the fence and like these types of shooters or are in the mood for a good tale, I'd say give it a try. It's certainly not a broken or terrible game, and I had some fun with it. Maybe you'll like it more than I did.

To sum it all up: Good story, bad gameplay

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Play an anti-hero like a poor man’s Max Payne in a third person shooter with a gritty semi-realistic storyline.  The game appears to have co-op functionality, but I don’t think you can go through the single player campaign with a friend. Also, the game uses Games for Windows Live.

You play the campaign as Kane, a former mercenary indebted to a powerful crime group with international dealings. By indebted, I mean they own you and will kill your family if you don’t pay them back what you owe. The group has tasked Lynch, a low level thug as your new partner, and he’ll be tagging along with you to make sure you behave. Unfortunately Lynch has some serious problems, which add considerably to your own situation.

The game is played as a third person shooter where you can pick up the weapons your fallen enemies drop, and/or request ammo from one of your allies (usually Lynch). There are maybe a dozen guns to choose from but some are noticeably better than others (stronger, more precise).  There’s even a rocket launcher on a few levels to take care of tanks/helicopters. An important distinction is that unlike the Max Payne games, you have a “regenerating health” system instead of a standard health bar. This means if you take damage, you just have to hide for a few seconds and you’ll fully recover. This of course means the game is faster paced and you’re going to be more likely to try daring Rambo style attacks or charge enemy positions.

Pros:
+I mentioned the gritty storyline, and I actually enjoyed it. The “hero” Kane makes all sorts of stupid but believable decisions, and his new partner Lynch is even dumber. There are no “good guys” in this game, as is probably the case among real world criminal thugs.
+This is straightforward action, no puzzle solving or map exploring. You won’t get “lost” while playing this game, which I appreciate when I want to just blast my way through a mediocre game in one afternoon.

Cons:
-The game’s graphics are lackluster for something less than 10 years old, and the gameplay can be kind of clunky. I am told that if you have Windows 10, you will not be able to adequately run this game.
-I mentioned blasting my way through the game in one afternoon, and by that I mean the game is like 5 hours long. Hope you got it for a cheap price because there really isn’t that much replay value.

Overall, I don’t regret playing the game, but I’m glad I got it from a Humble Bundle because there’s nothing about it that’s “awesome.” Not horrible either though.
6.5/10

reviewText:
On one hand you have Kane. He's calm, collected, has his stuff in order, but nothing ever seems to go his way. On the other hand, you have Lynch. He's psychotic and prone to being a complete screw-up, but at least he's consistent. This dynamic duo is out to do what they do best, kill a ton of people, and...and...and?

There's a plot to this madness, but expect it to kinda fall by the wayside after the first hour and a half. It's clear to me that IO interactive had some great ideas, but they forgot to put it all together for most of the game. reviewText:
It says I played 13 minutes, but that's because I had to mess around to get this working and ended up running the exe from the folder instead, so when I finished the single player none of my time was clocked.

There is a horrendous bug in this game, it will stutter every 4-5 seconds at all times, the cause of this is USB devices it seems, I had to unplug my mouse in order to play without the stutter up until about mid-way when the stutter came back but less abrasive. Other people had to disable all HID devices in order to play, there is almost no help online, the publisher(Square Enix) rushed this port, dumped it and abandoned it, Windows Live is still in the game, but it didn't cause me trouble I just backed out of it and played the single player.

The multiplayer no longer functions as Windows Live is dead now, so don't expect coop or anything else the multiplayer contained, it's gone now.

On to the game itself, I'll start by saying the story is the only redeeming part of this game apart from places where the combat raises itself to mediocre. The game stinks of early 7th generation TPS. The worst offender is the shooting mechanics, the guns are inherently inaccurate no matter what you aim at you'll have to shoot it almost thirty times just to land a hit, there is a reticule on screen, but if you're more than 10 feet from your target, every shot will land around the centre of the reticule.

It's horrible.

There are other mechanics to speak about like the horrible squad mates that will either follow you and kill one enemy every 5 minutes or attack an enemy you tagged to attack, regardless of all the enemies in-between, they will march into a hail of hot metal for one enemy, and when they get downed, you have to revive them.

Oh and just for good measure they threw in some forced stealth sections that are instant-fail and can be failed by one of your 5 squad mates wandering into the enemy's line of sight, so, that's fun.

It's about 4~ hours long and only good for the story and some really nice levels, but overall it's only worth playing once.

Don't pay over €2 for it, if you really have to, keep it under €5.

That's if you can get it running without audio or video issues.

reviewText:
Well, I'm not far into the game but I will revise this review once I get done with Kane & Lynch. Apart from that I think 1.5 hours are a crucial time to decide if a game is going to be worth your time or not.
I can only speak for Single-Player - maybe the Multi-player makes more fun - but this game has aged.
The downs: Horrible aiming - try to do a headshot and you will face problems like - each 2nd shot goes somewhere else as you have planned AND if you are in cover your crosshairs may point at someone's face but in reality you will shoot your cover or any nearby object which is in the way! I don't know if this issues are the same with a controller but I assume so. Gunplay is very imprecise which is a big downer.
Apart from that the other cons: Very linear gameplay and story progression - no exploration needed nor wanted - the areas are very small and limited, only one way in only one way out.
Too much cutscenes and cinematics (all of them quite short). The pretty much break any immersion. Furthermore each chapter is really short which interupts any fluid gameplay.
Another point which bothers me is that the environments are really cold and generic. There is no attention payed to a detailed surrounding whatsoever. I know this game is out there for some years now but other games from that time have done better than this.
Can this game still be fun? Yes, it has potential and certainly its moments.
It's rock-solid violence carried out by callous dogs and may be great fun in Co-op but as already said this game has its limitations.
On the other side you can just pick it up and play. And it will run on your machine most certainly.
So this is it folks, my first negative review with some positive aspects.
-Yours Bethlemos-

PS: Right now if you pick it up on sale it may be worth your money. So if you want to invest a buck - go for it.

I would recommend Kane and Lynch: Dead Men as a bargain, below average FPS.

reviewText:
A painfully average and forgettable game that isn't particularily interesting or memorable in the slightest, as there are really no defining features that make Kane and Lynch stand out compared to other shooters. The game mechanics are serviceable for the time but third person cover based shooters have been done far better in more recent years and there is really not much else to the game in terms of features, it just feels like cover based shooting moving to cover based shooting throughout the whole game. The game's story is very bland and uninteresting, neither Kane nor Lynch are particularily interesting characters and the game doesn't do much with the setup of villain protagonists to make memorable characters and story. The game abandons the urban environments two thirds into the game and becomes another generic jungle military style game. Its also far too short; I beat it on normal in around 5 hours. Also, co op doesn't work because it has GFWL.

Probably the most memorable part of the game is an early mission inside the nightclub. You have to make your way through a crowded nightclub while using a hostage as a human shield, you're limited to just a pistol and the enemy gang members are hidden within the crowd and aren't immediately visable, it reminded me of some of the crowded party missions in Hitman: Blood Money. If there were more interesting or memorable segments like this, the game may have been worth playing but moments like this a lost in a sea of forgettable shooting segments.

If you want to play a single player crime game where you control a group of criminals and plan heists, play Grand Theft Auto V instead. Kane and Lynch is definitely not worth playing unless you want a short, generic crime shooter that you can beat in an afternoon and then forget about.

reviewText:
This was a surprisingly good game. It's not great by any means, but if you can be forgiving of its shortcomings, the plot will reward you.

PROS
+ Excellent story. The setup drags a little bit, but once you're into the meat of things, it keeps you hooked.
+ A solid script, characters who are less heroic than your average shooter, and nice voice-acting add a lot of gravitas.
+ There are some truly great setpieces worth experiencing, namely a shootout in a crowded nightclub and a moving daylight shootout through the streets of Tokyo. They're reminiscent of Michael Mann movies like Collateral and Heat.
+ The squad commands allow you to employ some complex tactics in firefights, advancing under covering fire, guarding each other's flanks, etc.
+ Some inspired moments of art direction.

CONS
- The weakest levels and least polish - including an atrocious driving level - are all up front, meaning that if you bounce off the game you'll bounce off hard.
- The A.I. isn't terrible, but the things that it does well - flanking and maneuvers - are limited by linear level design that doesn't cater to it and exposes its weaknesses.
- The cover system is inconsistent. You'll abandon it pretty quickly, not that it makes a huge difference in the gameplay.
- Lack of polish abounds. Jagged edges, texture bugging on an early level, some too-simple level design.
- Games for Windows. We all know why.

PRO OR CON???
There are some nasty difficulty spikes, even on Easy mode. It takes some trial and error. Normally, that kind of unevenness wears thin very quickly for me, but something about the story kept me going at it anyway.

This is a SOFT RECOMMENDATION. It's not a big money risk, given its sale prices now, and you can finish it in a few evenings max, so it's not a big time sink either. Story's worth it, and a few moments are very memorable.

reviewText:
Kane & Lynch: Dead Men


Pros-

#1.Lynch is interesting

#2.Many different maps

#3.Co-op.I have not tried it but at least there is the option

#4.The story is unique in the sense that there is no good guys"

#5.There is multiplayer but there was nobody online playing for me to try it


Cons-

#1.The AI is really stupid and unrealistic and will kill the game for some people

#2.The story is nothing special but Lynch is the one good thing in it

#3.The cover system and the aiming system both hurt the game and should of been improved

#4.Not being able to skip cut scenes.I don't remember if I could skip some of them but I know for sure I couldn't skip them all and that sucked

#5.The swearing is in overkill.I swear every day but it seemed a little excessive in this game.I could be wrong on this as I have no idea what the average prisoner or robber in America would call excessive swearing

#6.I didn't like the ending of the game

The selfish ending where he leaves the men behind to die seemed realistic.You shouldn't feel happy or rewarded for being selfish.I would of taken this ending out of the game anyway because it sucks even if it is realistic

The saving your men ending I didn't like it either.I think Kane should of died and Lynch and Jenny should of escaped

I know that was not realistic since they were planning to make another Kane and Lynch game which they did.Kane would obviously have to survive both endings.I would rather Lynch got his own game

I just would of felt more sorry for Kane if he had died.I didn't find Kane to be interesting or likable.With his daughter dying I felt sorry for her and not him.If he had died than they could of shown her forgiving him.I think that would of been the best ending



The Bottom Line -

Kane & Lynch: Dead Men is not for everyone.The gameplay is a thumbs down but the game does have a variety of different map locations.Lynch was the only interesting part of the story

The game is made by the same people who make the hitman games.I kept waiting for 47 to show up because it looks so similar to the hitman series.Do not be confused the hitman games are much better than this.Hitman Blood Money has better graphics and gameplay and is older then K and L

Kane & Lynch also reminded me of the Max Payne series in the sense of nothing seems to go right for Max or Kane.The Max Payne games are much better than K and L so don't read too much into my comparison

If I was you then I would pass on Kane & Lynch: Dead Men.The gameplay being the most important reason.The AI being so stupid and how hard it can be to aim at targets that are easily in range of the guns you shoot is very unrealistic

If you must buy it then get it $5 or less on steam and have low expectations


My 2 cents

reviewText:
Kane & Lynch: Dead Men is a third person shooter game with a few interesting twists, but ultimately the poor execution of some elements drag it down quite a bit.

First off I've played this game a bit when it came out on Xbox, did a little bit of coop back then, but never finished it. It has been sitting in my Steam library for a while now until I recently decided to finish it. The game itself was released in a time where things were still good in the gaming business and companies churned out games at a fast pace. It was also a high time for Xbox and most relevantly coop was the thing every game needed to have.

STORY
The game takes an interesting perspective from the bad guy who gets broken out of prison and is confronted with his past. Needless to say life as a mercenary is shady and he did some things his former employers couldn't agree with. His wife and daughter are leveraged and he is blackmailed into retrieving something. Beyond that the story gets rather predictive with failure and revenge as central pivoting points.

GAMEPLAY
As said the game is a third person shooter and the controls handle a bit slow and rough, but when playing with the controller everything runs pretty good.
Cover mechanics however are poorly done and for some reason you can only get in cover on the edge of a wall, even the lower ones. This is very frustrating since enemies are abundant and aim pretty good, even on the lowest difficulty.
On the other hand most of your weapons have such low accuracy you really have to get very close to hit something. Result is that moving from cover to cover gets you killed most of the time, luckily your team-mates revive you almost every time.
And that is pretty much the only thing they get right, other than that they're pretty useless. You have a few basic commands, but anything other than 'Stay here' or 'Come over' is pointless. You can order them to attack a specific target, but this just results in them rushing towards it and shooting them in the face with a shotgun. The animation however is pretty nice though. That's mostly the gameplay throughout the game, aside from a few vehicle missions.

VISUALS
The game is a bit older, but it still looks acceptable, but nothing special. There is some destructibility, which was also very popular back then. Most animations in the game appear somewhat crude, but then again acceptable for it's age. It should run pretty good on today's laptops as a counter argument.

AUDIO
The audio is nothing to be noted specifically, no orchestral scores. Just your standard background music with a few tension increasing tempos. The voice acting, including lip sync, is actually pretty good for the standard of those days. But the dialogs happen mostly during game, which can be very incomprehensible at times. However most of them are restricted to a lot of swearing and banter, so you won't miss much.

MULTIPLAYER
As said the game can be played coop and it will be waaaay more fun when playing with some buddies, like with much of these coop games. Also the online versus mode is very original, especially with a name like Fragile Alliance, things can get interesting. You can view the tutorial and get an impression of what it would be like, but that's about it. Servers are dead, both coop and versus. So sadly I cannot divulge into this any further, but I can expect it would change my opinion of the game.

VERDICT
Buy it cheap if you want to experience the beginning of the franchise, but other than that just skip it and go straight to the next one. If you have enough friends who are willing to play it with you I would probably recommend this one for sure. Most coop games from previous generation are well worth it just for that.

reviewText: This is a highly under-rated game and I highly recommend playing it despite the multiplayer being completely dead. I bought this game the year it came out on Xbox 360 even after multiple friends had given me bad reviews on it. Instead of putting this one up on the shelf to collect dust, I played through the campaign multiple times, and again even with friends and family. The CO-OP is a blast, and I really enjoyed the multiplayer as it was around. The multiplayer was quite comparable to the PayDay franchise, except that there was a twist; as you tried to rob the location with your fellow team they as well as yourself had the option to betray eachother. The winner took all, or if you did decide to work together you got to split the money. The multiplayer was short and sweet, but because you could not do much with the money, or beyond the level of customization it seemed to quickly face it's demize. Although multiplayer is now dead, the gameplay and story still make this an enjoying title for the price. If you have ever played the 2006 Reservoir Dogs or even have played PayDay 1 or 2, you are in for a similar experience. As Multiplayer gaming dominates the market, this franchise is one of the last I have seen with a truly CO-OP experience. Pick this game up... You cannot go wrong for the price!

I got this and the second game reeeeeaaaaaal cheap, like £1 for both games, so yeah bargain, i don't regret the 50p spent on this game but it is...mediocre at best. The gameplay is really janky and a lot of the time when you shoot someone when they are behind cover your bullet won't hit them and just goes through them instead, causing you to either wait for them to move or you being forced to move into different cover to take them out.

There's a nice assortment of different environments and levels to play through including a prison, bank, a nightclub, the streets of japan and even some jungle levels late on in the game. I have to say actually that the nightclub level in this is probably the best nightclub i have seen in a game so far, it had really immersive strobe lighting and was packed with 100's of NPC's who then run around screaming when you inevitably have a shootout in it. Compare this to the clubs in games like Deus ex or Sleeping Dogs and there's no comparison, and this game came out in 2007 so that's impressive to me. Only the new Hitman game and the new Assassins Creed Unity has really played around with interactive crowd density.

It's weird though because the actual story about Kane and Lynch has had no effort put into it BUT the actual characters all have more personality than you would expect in a game like this and i found the voice acting really well done as well, i actually wanted to finish the game to see where the story went. It's just why and how Kane and Lynch continue to work with each other had me saying WTF!!!! Lynch is a psychopath who kills innocent people for no reason and then has a blackout where he doesn't even remember doing it. Later on in the game Kane has him keep his ex japanese girlfriend hostage, and without spoiling it you can tell that isn't going to end well. If they were brothers i could understand it but they just met each other and another character who you break out of prison even says he doesn't wanna work with Lynch because he's a crazy b*stard and killed his own wife. They have a character in the game who gets it! so why doesn't Kane? it's stupid and they could have made that way more believable if they just spent more time on the writing

I would actually recommend this game purely for the nightclub level, the rest of the game is ok if you can get past some of the jank.

Recommended, although some flaws are really annoying and it is not that good game. But if you buy it on sale, it's OK for the money.

It's just simple 3rd person shooter, where you are really bad guy, things go bad and you are going bad and at the end - no, it is not Hollywood story.

Unfortunately, gameplay is flawed.
1. Companions are pretty stupid, those additional non-core are dying too quickly and probably the most important command is to keep close, otherwise they rush forward into trouble.
2. Cover system is bug itself - you never knows, whether it is engaged or not when you approach proper place. That end up in troubles and deaths, because you want to move and you are locked to cover, or you want to pop-up and spray enemy and you are not - and you move and expose yourself to fire.
3. you cannot pick-up ammo of the same type when from different weapon (OK, mags are not always interchangeable, but this is not hardcore sim)

All the time you are exposed to fire and as enemy is eventually closing in meantime, you may realize, that he is too close, but you hardly can do anything than waste the first grenade by overthrowing and go for another one.
5. sometimes you start scripted spawn of enemies at closed, empty place, just around you, that leads to pretty nasty ends.


So, why to recommend? Well, if you don't pay too much and do not expect great game, it is still relatively decent game, with some good moments, ending - although scripted - is fair and rough as you may expect for somebody dancing with devil. Last mission - if you choose to go through it - has cinematic atmosphere.
Should developers at least made shoot-outs more intense, gave you chance to flank enemies or force/allow you to move from position to position to get advantage it would be better game despite the flaws.

reviewText:
I kind of enjoyed this game, but overall I have to say that it is NOT worth it.

First of all, just to get the game running you need to download Games for Windows Live, which is pretty annoying in itself, but I've heard that some people (namely those on Windows 10) can't run the game at all.  That by itself is enough to make me not really want this game, but I decided to play it anyway.

As for the actual game, it's nothing great.  The gameplay is alright.  It's a mediocre cover based shooter at best.  I only really had trouble with one area of the game.  My biggest complaint about the gameplay is that most of the guns feel the same.  You have pistol, shotgun, automatic weapons, and single shot weapons.  They made several different automatic weapons, but they all handle roughly the same.  The game is also really short.  It only took me about 5 hours to beat, and the replay value is almost nonexistent, which sucks.  It's also annoying how the HUD only shows how much ammo you have for your weapon, not how many bullets are in the magazine.  A lot of minor inconveniences come together to really bring the game down.

Despite how bad the gameplay is, the story is probably what disappointed me the most.  Kane gets busted out of prison and is forced to work with the men who betrayed a while back (you never find out what he did).  One issue that I had with the story was that there was little to no foreshadowing.  Now foreshadowing isn't necessary for a story, but you have no idea what's going to happen until it happens, and then you feel confused because you don't really know why it happened, or if there was any hint to it before.  The story wasn't anything great, but it was the main reason that I played to the end...  and boy did it let me down.  The game lets you choose between 2 endings, both of which leave a bad taste in your mouth.  I won't spoil it if any of you want to see it, but just take it from me it isn't worth it.

Overall, this game just isn't worth your time.  If you want a cover based shooter, there are thousands of better ones, and if you really want to know the story, just look it up.

reviewText:
Kane & Lynch: Dead Men is a third person shooter game with a few interesting twists, but ultimately the poor execution of some elements drag it down quite a bit.

First off I've played this game a bit when it came out on Xbox, did a little bit of coop back then, but never finished it. It has been sitting in my Steam library for a while now until I recently decided to finish it. The game itself was released in a time where things were still good in the gaming business and companies churned out games at a fast pace. It was also a high time for Xbox and most relevantly coop was the thing every game needed to have.

STORY
The game takes an interesting perspective from the bad guy who gets broken out of prison and is confronted with his past. Needless to say life as a mercenary is shady and he did some things his former employers couldn't agree with. His wife and daughter are leveraged and he is blackmailed into retrieving something. Beyond that the story gets rather predictive with failure and revenge as central pivoting points.

GAMEPLAY
As said the game is a third person shooter and the controls handle a bit slow and rough, but when playing with the controller everything runs pretty good.
Cover mechanics however are poorly done and for some reason you can only get in cover on the edge of a wall, even the lower ones. This is very frustrating since enemies are abundant and aim pretty good, even on the lowest difficulty.
On the other hand most of your weapons have such low accuracy you really have to get very close to hit something. Result is that moving from cover to cover gets you killed most of the time, luckily your team-mates revive you almost every time.
And that is pretty much the only thing they get right, other than that they're pretty useless. You have a few basic commands, but anything other than 'Stay here' or 'Come over' is pointless. You can order them to attack a specific target, but this just results in them rushing towards it and shooting them in the face with a shotgun. The animation however is pretty nice though. That's mostly the gameplay throughout the game, aside from a few vehicle missions.

VISUALS
The game is a bit older, but it still looks acceptable, but nothing special. There is some destructibility, which was also very popular back then. Most animations in the game appear somewhat crude, but then again acceptable for it's age. It should run pretty good on today's laptops as a counter argument.

AUDIO
The audio is nothing to be noted specifically, no orchestral scores. Just your standard background music with a few tension increasing tempos. The voice acting, including lip sync, is actually pretty good for the standard of those days. But the dialogs happen mostly during game, which can be very incomprehensible at times. However most of them are restricted to a lot of swearing and banter, so you won't miss much.

MULTIPLAYER
As said the game can be played coop and it will be waaaay more fun when playing with some buddies, like with much of these coop games. Also the online versus mode is very original, especially with a name like Fragile Alliance, things can get interesting. You can view the tutorial and get an impression of what it would be like, but that's about it. Servers are dead, both coop and versus. So sadly I cannot divulge into this any further, but I can expect it would change my opinion of the game.

VERDICT
Buy it cheap if you want to experience the beginning of the franchise, but other than that just skip it and go straight to the next one. If you have enough friends who are willing to play it with you I would probably recommend this one for sure. Most coop games from previous generation are well worth it just for that.

Kane & Lynch: Dead Men is a vastly misunderstood game due to how far it departs from the standard for the genre, and the Gerstmann gate controversy surrounding it that the publishers, not developers, were responsible for.

Firearms aren't as accurate, more like a realistic firefight and a way to lengthen the interactions between player and enemy AI - which take place in a very Michael Mann rific tribute, for the most part. There is no real hero, the atmosphere is far bleaker, not pretending to say you should root for Kane - he is a bad, bad person.

You're the bad guys. Wasting away at regular cops, innocent people, other bad guys, and so on. It's an oddly fascinating experience coming from a storytelling perspective.

---

Essentially, Kane and Lynch is far from perfect with bugs, a few frustrating moments, a somewhat lackluster ending, but it's far more satisfying than Gears of War and it's obnoxious football jocks.

Summary: Short, uninspired, buggy.

Kane & Lynch as an idea has all the elements that make Hitman, developed also by IO, work. A contracted killer, here a mercenary that worked as part of a group rather than a lone hitman, bound for death row, gets out of prison by his old group to make amends. His family is kidnapped and he has to comply to save them. Although a bit cliche, the story could work, but it simply doesn't. The characters are underdeveloped, the plot never gets deeper, while large gaps are left to fill in with your imagination.

Gameplay-wise, the gunplay isn't anything to write home about, reminding of linear FPS that were considered outdated even by 2007 standards, with bullet-sponge enemies. The guns are often inaccurate, even in short distances and while firing with discipline (aiming, short bursts etc.). The cover system doesn't always work and sometimes while you are in cover you still get shot without the situation justifying it (e.g. when covering behind solid rock or cement that shouldn't be pierced by bullets. The AI is laughable, with some covering the wrong way opening themselves to shots, or when in groups just running straight at you, which diminishes any sense that you are fighting actual opponents.

The game requires Games for Windows Live, and in newer systems you have to find out on your own and download the client yourself in order for the game to launch. Multiplayer is long-dead, co-op is off-line only, the campaign is short (I finished it in ~6 hours while really taking my time). There's also a few crashes and glitches, although this is an afterthought in the game which is already dissapointing.

I got this as part of a bundle and it was as good as a movie you let play in the background. You can skip it safely and not miss anything, if you really want to play the second one (haven't played that yet, so no idea if it any good), just read the plot online, you're not missing anything.

reviewText:
I kind of enjoyed this game, but overall I have to say that it is NOT worth it.

First of all, just to get the game running you need to download Games for Windows Live, which is pretty annoying in itself, but I've heard that some people (namely those on Windows 10) can't run the game at all.  That by itself is enough to make me not really want this game, but I decided to play it anyway.

As for the actual game, it's nothing great.  The gameplay is alright.  It's a mediocre cover based shooter at best.  I only really had trouble with one area of the game.  My biggest complaint about the gameplay is that most of the guns feel the same.  You have pistol, shotgun, automatic weapons, and single shot weapons.  They made several different automatic weapons, but they all handle roughly the same.  The game is also really short.  It only took me about 5 hours to beat, and the replay value is almost nonexistent, which sucks.  It's also annoying how the HUD only shows how much ammo you have for your weapon, not how many bullets are in the magazine.  A lot of minor inconveniences come together to really bring the game down.

Despite how bad the gameplay is, the story is probably what disappointed me the most.  Kane gets busted out of prison and is forced to work with the men who betrayed a while back (you never find out what he did).  One issue that I had with the story was that there was little to no foreshadowing.  Now foreshadowing isn't necessary for a story, but you have no idea what's going to happen until it happens, and then you feel confused because you don't really know why it happened, or if there was any hint to it before.  The story wasn't anything great, but it was the main reason that I played to the end...  and boy did it let me down.  The game lets you choose between 2 endings, both of which leave a bad taste in your mouth.  I won't spoil it if any of you want to see it, but just take it from me it isn't worth it.

Overall, this game just isn't worth your time.  If you want a cover based shooter, there are thousands of better ones, and if you really want to know the story, just look it up.

I grabbed this game on sale thinking that it was a good deal but in fact, any discount won't ever make it any better. I still played it to the end so I will give you a quick review -no spoiler- of why you should not get this game, whatever the price.
The game is a shooter, with some extremely limited squad management involved. You play as an inmate on the run from death row. Now with that in mind, I will start with the qualities of the game:
-It is fairly short and believe me, that's quite the relief.

...and done.Now, that's out of the way, I will list some of its many shortcomings:
-Its a port from the console and it shows. It's not very ugly but it is still pretty bad for a 2007 game. The optimization is non existent and the fps will drop even on a modern mid-range rig.
-The control are truly inadequate and moving around is really frustrating. Commanding the squad is not too hard but there ain't much you can order them anyway.
-Aiming is a royal pain, you always find yourself in a particular angle that prevents you from firing at the enemy. It is so cumbersome that you will find the cover system more effective at protecting the ones you are shooting at.
-The AI is stupid both for your enemies and allies. This makes the game really easy very often, especially in corridors. To compensate for this, you are regularly thrown in arenas where inordinate amounts of bad guys will spawn from all sides. Your teammates will be of very little help. It makes it more irritating than interesting.
-Finally, the scenario is very unoriginal and full of clichés. The English dubbing is only semi-convincing.

In short, better you replay one of your old favorite rather than trying this poor, generic game.

reviewText:
In my older days, this game was the absolutely sickest game I've ever played. I think it had something to do with my first real desktop computer. Even though back then my graphic card sucked and I could barely play it still brings back good memories. The only thing that didn't was the Games for Windows Live. And even though I now own the Steam Version of the game I can see on the forum that it is still a big issue. So if you can't remember your password to Windows Live you're pretty much screwed and you can spend hours just to download all the updates, patches just to be able to play the game.

I know the game didn't really get a lot of positive reviews and there was a lot of drama surrounding this game due to a little company called GameSpot, but that's a different story. Speaking of stories. The game is about a criminal, who's in jail writing a letter to her daughter Jenny. Some dudes, help him escape and he found himself in a chair bounded and is asked to deliver back the money he stole from his old teammates. They have kidnapped her daughter until Kane delivers it back to them. To guard him, they hire a watchdog (Lynch) to look out for him and the journey begins.

It wasn't so long time ago I actually replayed this game and it didn't quite live up my expectations of what I remembered. The game hasn't really aged very well. The gameplay is not as snappy you would probably like. It feels all a bit clunky and not responsive at all. The cover system is a bit average and so is the gunplay. It has some decent graphics for its time and interesting locations and missions overall, but the story falls a bit flat and that's Kane and Lynch weakness. The writing of the game is not really interesting either. They use a lot of swear words, not there's anything wrong with that, but they constantly use it, and it becomes tiring. You have a squad you can use by calling commands, but it's never really used properly, and you're in most cases better of alone.

Conclusion, yes Kane and Lynch falls flat on pretty much every level, but it's not a bad game per se, it's just that it's so average and doesn't bring up whole new set of stuff. I've also heard that the game doesn't really work well on the most graphics card, so it's probably not optimised well, but that's just what I read on the forum. I'm going to recommend this game anyway, just because it holds a nostalgia value for me and I would probably also have picked it up sometime anyway. If you want to play with your friends you can do coop, but it doesn't really advance the story in any particularly way. So try it out and see if it's something for you.

reviewText: Kane and Lynch is one of the most memorable games to me, yet not exactly one of my favorites. I enjoyed it back when it was released, beating it several times on Xbox 360. I was impressed by how they managed to create such violent and depressing atmosphere in a story about characters who are downright insane in a disturbingly twisted way. The game feels like it was planned to be actually big, but after going through rough feature cuts it turned out to be what it is, a story-driven cover-based TPS with plot holes and the most basic of TPS mechanics you can find.\nBut the story and atmosphere is what deserves some attention in K&L. Heard of the night club level? Or sieging a business skyscraper dressed as window washers? Give this game a shot. Seriously, it deserves to at least be tried.\nThe reason I give it a thumbs down though lies in this exact Steam version. This is not actually a Steam version, to be exact - it probably won't even work when you buy and install it before you get Microsoft's Game Marketplace installed. I still own a disc version and can confirm that it's the same edition with absolutely no differences (except the MS Game Market is installed along with the game not making you confused about why it doesn't launch). For best experience get it on used disc or play it on your console of choise. Putting aside all technical details, the atmosphere deserves your attention. Just give it a shot.
